Graphical abstract Reinforced Lewis covalent bond induced by twinborn nitride heterostructure as the sulfur host enhances the Lewis covalent bond with S, catalyzes redox reactions, and improves the e− and Li+ transmission. The practical application of lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries, as promising next-generation batteries, is hindered by their shuttle effect and the slow redox kinetics. Herein, a tungsten and molybdenum nitride heterostructure functionalized with hollow metal-organic framework-derived carbon (W2N/Mo2N) was proposed as the sulfur host. The hollow spherical structure provides storage space for sulfur, enhances electrical conductivity, and inhibits volume expansion. The metal atoms in the nitrides bonded with lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) through Lewis covalent bonds, enhancing the high catalytic activity of the nitrides and effectively reducing the energy barrier of LiPSs redox conversion. Moreover, the high intrinsic conductivity of nitrides and the ability of the heterostructure interface to accelerate electron/ion transport improved the Li+ transmission. By leveraging the combined properties of strong adsorption and high catalytic activity, the sulfur host effectively inhibited the shuttle effect and accelerated the redox kinetics of LiPSs. High-efficiency Li+ transmission, strong adsorption, and the efficient catalytic conversion activities of LiPSs in the heterostructure were experimentally and theoretically verified. The results indicate that the W2N/Mo2N cathode provides stable, and long-term cycling (over 2000 cycles) at 3 C with a low attenuation rate of 0.0196% per cycle. The design strategy of a twinborn nitride heterostructure thus provides a functionalized solution for advanced Li-S batteries. Keywords Heterostructure Adsorption Redox kinetics 1 Introduction Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries offer numerous theoretical advantages, such as ultra-high energy density (2600 Wh kg−1), high theoretical capacity (1673 mA h g−1), rich raw material storage, and environmental friendliness. However, these benefits are hindered by low conductivity (S8: 5 × 10−30 S cm−1 and Li2S: 3.6 × 10−7 S cm−1), volume expansion (S8: 2.07 g cm−3 and Li2S: 1.66 g cm−3), and the production of multi lithium sulfide (LiPSs) which leads to the dissolution and shuttle of slow redox kinetics [1–9]. As the redox site of active material sulfur and Li2S, the cathode of Li-S battery has a decisive impact on the overall performance of the battery through the kinetics and thermodynamic process of the electrode. Effective sulfur host design can address the above issues and maximize the advantages of Li-S batteries [10–13]. The existing research on cathode mainly focuses on building suitable carrier materials to enhance conductivity and inhibit volume expansion during charging and discharging and on introducing catalytic active sites to accelerate the redox process of LiPSs. Due to its excellent electronic transmission capacity and three-dimensional interconnection properties, carbon materials as cathode materials of Li-S batteries can effectively carry sulfur and inhibit the dissolution of long-chain LiPSs to some extent [14–16]. However, its uneven distribution of elements can lead to electrode scale oxidation/reduction reaction heterogeneity in the battery, which in turn increases the complexity of electrochemical reactions. Metal-organic framework derived carbon (MOF-C) with a regular framework structure and uniformly distributed carbon atoms can serve as an excellent conductive substrate to address the above issues. Hollow MOF-C is well used in Li-S batteries, improving material conductivity while ensuring reaction uniformity. In addition, its semi sealed structure can prevent the dissolution of LiPSs, and the large specific surface area helps to load sufficient functional sites to catalyze electrochemical reactions. In recent years, the cathode electrode materials of Li-S batteries are no longer limited to a certain inorganic material additive. A unique heterojunction structure has attracted widespread attention, and its structure itself has a gain effect on lithium ion migration. In addition, it is commonly observed that the materials used to construct heterojunctions possess both adsorption and catalytic effects, leading to an effect of ″1 + 1 > 2″ [17–20]. As a component that can be used to construct heterojunctions, transition metal nitrides have the advantages of high conductivity, good stability, strong adsorption ability, and excellent catalytic performance [21–26]. However, a single compound is inadequate for handling the complex process of polysulfide conversion on its own. Therefore, combining two different metal nitrides and utilizing their advantages are proved to be an effective strategy to solve the problem of continuous change in Li-S batteries [27]. Molybdenum nitride [28–30] has shown potential as an inhibitor of the shuttle effect of LiPSs in the Li-S system. This is attributed to its formidable chemical bond and dispersion interaction with LiPSs, in addition to the covalent activation mechanism generated by Lewis acid on its surface. Additionally, it promotes the decomposition of lithium sulfide by reducing the combination of lithium–sulfur bonds [31–33]. Therefore, by constructing heterostructures, tungsten and molybdenum nitrides can be combined to optimize their chemical/physical properties, provide more active surface sites, and improve conductivity. In a previous study [34], our team built a heterojunction of molybdenum disulfide and molybdenum nitride to catalyze the conversion of LiPSs. The designed cathode electrode had good long-term cycling performance. In our current study, we built upon our previous work and constructed heterostructures using bimetallic nitrides (W2N/Mo2N) and combined them with MOF-C based on zinc metal organic framework derived carbon. This created a sulfur host known as W2N/Mo2N@MOF-C. First, the semi-enclosed, hollow, and spherical structure of W2N/Mo2N was beneficial for buffering the volume expansion during sulfur loading and charge-discharge processes, and initially inhibited the dissolution of LiPSs. Second, the W2N/Mo2N heterostructure provided a combination of strong adsorption and catalysis. The adsorption of LiPSs was realized through Lewis covalent bond, lithium bond, and Van der Waals force. In addition, the high conductivity provided by the heterostructure interface, accelerating of electron and ion transport, improved the conversion efficiency of LiPSs. The heterostructure also reduced the energy barriers for LiPSs oxidation and reduction, as well as electron and ion migration. Due to its excellent adsorption and catalytic capability, the W2N/Mo2N@MOF-C cathode provided stable long cycle performance and high-capacity retention at 3 C. 2 Results and discussion The Scheme1 illustrates the theoretical design strategies of the W2N/Mo2N heterostructure sulfur host. First, MOF-C was introduced as a substrate to improve the conductivity of the sulfur host, and the preliminary confinement for polysulfide was achieved through the hollow structure. Then, uniformly distributed W2N/Mo2N heterostructures were constructed on the flocculent structure of MOF-C. The strong adsorption and catalytic abilities were offered by the W2N/Mo2N heterostructure, and the accelerated electron and ion transmission at heterostructure interface was realized owing to its intrinsic high conductivity and built-in electric field. The adsorption of LiPSs was achieved through Lewis covalent bonds, lithium bonds, and Van der Waals forces. Further, the high conductivity, accelerating electron and ion transmission, was offered by the heterogeneous interface. Its catalytic ability was combined to improve the conversion efficiency of LiPSs, electron and ion migration, as well as reduce the oxidation and reduction energy barrier of LiPSs. The dynamics of battery reactions was accelerated ultimately. The W2N/Mo2N heterojunction was prepared by oxidation and nitridation of g-phase carbon nitride compound (g-C3N4), and some intermediates were characterized (Figs. S1 and S2). Afterwards, the heterojunction and functionalized MOF-C were combined as sulfur carrying cathode electrodes (W2N/Mo2N@MOF-C）(detailed steps had been displayed in the Supporting Information). Fig. 1 (a) illustrates the scanning electron microscope (SEM) images of W2N/Mo2N, which shows the uniform distribution of spheres with diameter of 1–4 μm. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images at different magnifications (Fig. 1a–d) show that W2N/Mo2N had a uniformly distributed hollow spherical structure. Much of the flocculent structure was densely distributed on the edge of the sphere. The hollow structure can be used as a sulfur storage area to facilitate the inhibition of LiPSs dissolution and volume expansion during charge and discharge. The flocculent structure significantly increased the active specific surface area of the sulfur host. It enabled the loaded active site to fully contact with the active substance, giving full play to the adsorption and catalytic capacity of the active site at the sulfur, carbon substrate, and electrolyte interface. Fig. 1(e) presents the crystal structure of W2N/Mo2N, where the (200) crystal planes of Mo2N and (111) crystal planes of W2N form a heterostructure. A high-resolution TEM image of the flocculent structure is shown in Fig. 1(f). Lighter-colored structures representing amorphous carbon were observed, and many small dark areas were evenly distributed on the surface of these carbon structures. The W2N/Mo2N heterostructure formed by the (200) crystal plane of Mo2N and the (111) crystal plane of W2N was observed in each dark area. Fig. 1(g) shows the TEM mapping of W2N/Mo2N@MOF under the scale bar of 500 nm and elements distribution of C, N, W, and Mo. The distribution of the P element owing to precursor residue and O element owing to oxidation was observed. The darker color of the elements at the edge of the hollow sphere was attributable to the even distribution of W2N and Mo2N in the floc structure at this edge. Additional SEM mapping images of W2N/Mo2N@MOF are shown in Fig. S3. From it, we can see a uniform distribution of C, N, W, and Mo elements. This can preliminarily confirm the presence of W2N and Mo2N on carbon substrates. To further analyze the crystal structure of the functional site, X-ray diffraction (XRD) tests were performed. The peaks of the three oxidized samples and MOF-C were consistent; the peak intensity and position of WO3/MoO3 had a high degree of coincidence with those of WO3 (PDF#41-0905) and MoO3 (PDF#21-0569), as shown in Fig. S4. Since point doping cannot afford large oxide crystals, the corresponding oxides do not show standard peaks. After nitriding, the XRD peaks shift to 40°. The XRD peaks of W2N/Mo2N coincide with those of W2N (PDF#25-1257) and Mo2N (PDF#25-1366), as shown in Fig. 1(h). Furthermore, the XRD patterns of Mo2N and W2N show the same results. The analysis of high-resolution TEM images shows that the distribution of W2N/Mo2N heterostructures did not appear to be in large sheets but was uniform owing to point doping, which leads to weaker XRD peak intensity and degree of coincidence. The above analyses confirm that the prepared W2N/Mo2N had a hollow spherical structure, and numerous W2N/Mo2N heterostructure functional sites were enriched on the surface flocculent structure. To verify that the as-prepared W2N/Mo2N had high specific surface area and suitable pore size for molten sulfur, specific surface area tests (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller, BET) were performed, as shown in Fig. 1(i) and Fig. S5. We find that MOF-C (1153.8 m2 g−1) had a higher accumulated specific surface area than W2N/Mo2N (204.9 m2 g−1), and the pore size distribution of both samples was between 5 and 10 nm. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption specific surface area was 2479.6 and 633.4 m2 g−1 for MOF-C and W2N/Mo2N, respectively. BET results show that MOF-C had a very large specific surface area, which was reduced to a certain extent after a large number of W2N/Mo2N heterostructures were doped. This also means that numerous active sites were attached to the active surface to adsorb and catalyze the transformation of LiPSs. XRD of three cathode electrode materials loaded with sulfur is shown in Fig. S6. Fig. S7 presents the crystal structures of Mo2N, W2N, and W2N/Mo2N heterostructure; the (200) crystal plane of Mo2N, (111) crystal plane of W2N, and the relative crystal plane gaps of Mo2N (200) and W2N (111) of W2N/Mo2N were adopted to perform relevant theoretical calculations. The total density of states (DOS) comparisons of the W2N/Mo2N heterostructure were shown in Fig. 1(j) to analyze its electronic structure. The band structures of W2N/Mo2N, Mo2N, and W2N are shown in Fig. S8. All three sulfur hosts had energy band distribution at the Fermi level, and the total density of states was not zero, which means that all three sulfur hosts show metal characteristics with electronic conductivity. The energy band curve of the W2N/Mo2N heterostructure had the largest slope and showed wide window distribution, which meant that the W2N/Mo2N heterostructure had the lowest effective electron mass at the high symmetry point, and the electron migration energy barrier was the lowest. The total density of states of the W2N/Mo2N heterostructure had the largest number of electronic states at the Fermi level. In summary, the electronic conductivity of W2N/Mo2N was the highest, followed by W2N, and that of Mo2N was the lowest. According to the energy band and total density of states, the electronic conductivity of the sulfur host was enhanced after the formation of the W2N/Mo2N heterostructure, which was more conducive to the electron transfer in the redox conversion of the battery. From the perspective of electronic transmission, the transmission rate of W2N/Mo2N heterostructure was higher, which meant that the electrochemical reaction inside the battery was faster, improving reaction kinetics. Thereby the performance of battery was enhanced. To verify the adsorption effect of W2N/Mo2N to LiPSs, a visible adsorption experiment was performed. Fig. S9(a) presents the initial state photos of W2N/Mo2N, W2N, Mo2N, and MOF-C immersed in the same concentration of Li2S4 solution. The optical photos after 24 h of adsorption are shown in Fig S9(b). The four sulfur hosts had different adsorption ability to Li2S4; W2N/Mo2N and Mo2N showed stronger adsorption ability than W2N and MOF-C, and the color of the solution was almost transparent. The optical photos for W2N/Mo2N and Mo2N during the adsorption process are illustrated in Fig. S9(c). Owing to the adsorption of Li2S4, the yellow solution was stratified, which confirmed the strong adsorption of W2N/Mo2N and Mo2N to LiPSs. The surface bonding after Li2S4 adsorption was investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) as shown in Fig. 2 (a–c). The S 2p and Li 1s spectra of W2N/Mo2N are shown in Fig. S10, and the XPS results of MOF-C are presented in Fig. S11. According to the W 4f peak in Fig. 2(a), only three groups of XPS peaks were observed before adsorption, representing the energy loss characteristic peaks of the W–N bond, W–O bond, and WO3 bond. As the XPS test was performed on the surface and the depth was less than 10 nm, a slight oxidation of the surface was unavoidable, which was the reason for the occurrence of the WO3 bond. After Li2S4 adsorption, a pair of 4f peaks representing W–S appeared, which confirmed the formation of a stable chemical bond between W and S and realized the anchoring of LiPSs. Fig. 2(b) presents the Mo 3d peak. Before adsorption, peaks representing the Mo–N and Mo–O bonds appeared. After adsorption, peaks representing the Mo–S bond also appeared. It is worth noting that the proportion of the peak area representing Mo–S was higher than that representing W, which meant that more Mo participated in the adsorption. The visible adsorption experiment revealed why the adsorption ability of Mo was stronger. Fig. 2(c) illustrates the N 1s peaks. The pyridinic nitrogen, pyrrole nitrogen, W–N, and Mo–N could be found before adsorption, where pyridinic nitrogen and pyrrole nitrogen appeared owing to nitriding. The peak representing the Li–N bond appeared in the N 1s spectrum after Li2S4 adsorption. According to the XPS results, the metal atoms in W2N/Mo2N could form stable Lewis covalent bonds with S, which was why W2N/Mo2N could successfully adsorb and inhibit the dissolution of LiPSs. Fig. 2(d) shows the ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) spectrums of the sulfur hosts before and after being immersed in the Li2S6 solution for 1 h. The LiPSs adsorption strength for the four sulfur hosts increased in order: MOF-C, W2N, Mo2N, and W2N/Mo2N. More UV-vis spectra are presented in Fig. S12. Fig. 2(e) presents the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curve of the symmetric cell at 20 mV s−1. When the electrolyte does not contain Li2S6, the current of sulfur hosts is negligible. However, the current curves of sulfur hosts appear when the electrolyte contains Li2S6, indicating that the adsorption and bond-forming interaction between the sulfur hosts and LiPSs in the electrolyte have occurred. Among them, W2N/Mo2N and Mo2N have larger integral area. Consistent with the relevant experimental results of LiPSs adsorption, among the sulfur hosts, that containing Mo2N had stronger adsorption and anchoring effects. To verify the adsorption models and binding energy of W2N/Mo2N, Mo2N, and W2N to LiPSs, theoretical calculations based on density functional theory (DFT) were performed. Because of the presence of a large number of metal atoms on the surface of the sulfur hosts, long-chain LiPSs were dissociated owing to excessive binding energy during the adsorption process. Thus, short-chain soluble Li2S4 and insoluble Li2S were selected for relevant theoretical calculations. The binding energy statistics are shown in Fig. 2(f). The binding energy of W2N/Mo2N to Li2S was −7.79 eV, which was higher than that of Mo2N (−7.54 eV) and W2N (−7.44 eV). Furthermore, the binding of W2N/Mo2N to Li2S4 was −25.71 eV, which was higher than that of Mo2N (−24.58 eV) and W2N (−23.72 eV). Fig. 2(g) presents the difference in charge density of Li2S4-adsorbed W2N/Mo2N. W and Mo atoms formed Lewis covalent bonds with S atoms, respectively, and the covalent bonds of shared S atoms between the heterostructure layers were reinforced. Fig. 2(h) illustrates the DOS of Li2S4-adsorbed W2N/Mo2N, and the overall metallicity did not significantly decrease after the adsorption of Li2S4. The difference in charge density of Li2S4- and Li2S-adsorbed W2N/Mo2N, Mo2N, and W2N is shown in Fig. S13. The ball-and-stick models of sulfur host to Li2S4 and Li2S are presented in Fig. S14. The overall energy band and density of state of the sulfur hosts calculated after Li2S4 and Li2S adsorption are shown in Fig. S15. After adsorbing Li2S4 and Li2S, W2N/Mo2N as a whole exhibits metallicity and has the highest number of electronic states at the Fermi level. It is worth noting that compared with Li2S4, the binding energy of the hosts to Li2S is reduced by 20 eV. When the number of S atoms decreased, the binding energy also sharply decreased, and when the number of S atoms increased, the occurring of dissociation indicates a strong interaction between S atoms and the sulfur hosts. The theoretical simulation results show that W2N/Mo2N has the strongest adsorption energy for Li2S4, followed by Mo2N and W2N, which is consistent with the relevant experimental results for adsorption. To investigate the catalytic ability of the sulfur host to LiPSs, the relevant energy barriers were theoretically calculated. Fig. 3 (a and b) presents the Li+ migration models of Mo2N, W2N, and W2N/Mo2N; the migration energy barrier is shown in Fig. 3(c). W2N/Mo2N had the lowest migration energy barrier, followed by W2N and finally Mo2N. The first-step decomposition model and energy barrier of Li2S on the surface of the sulfur host are shown in Fig. 3(d–f). Similar to the Li+ migration results, W2N/Mo2N had the lowest decomposition energy barrier, followed by W2N and Mo2N. Thus, W2N had the ability to reduce the energy barrier of Li+ migration and the decomposition in the reaction process of Li-S batteries, and W2N/Mo2N achieves the best catalytic effect after combining the advantages of W2N and Mo2N. To further quantify the catalytic effects on the nucleation and decomposition of Li2S, galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) tests were performed [35,36]. For Li-S batteries, the difference (ΔiR) between the quasi-open-circuit voltage (QOCV) and the constant current charge discharge voltage (CCV) at the appearance of the first discharge long plateau reflects the energy barrier of Li2S nucleation, and smaller ΔiR reflects the lower nucleation energy barrier [37]. The ΔiR value in the first charge-rest cycle during charging reflects the energy barrier of Li2S decomposition, and lower ΔiR indicates easier for Li2S to decompose. Fig. 3(g) presents the GITT charge-discharge curves of W2N/Mo2N at a scan rate of 0.2 mV s−1. The GITT charge-discharge curves of Mo2N, W2N, and MOF-C are illustrated in Fig. S16. Fig. 3(h) shows the statistics of the potential difference during the nucleation and decomposition of Li2S. The nucleation potential difference of W2N/Mo2N was 26.4 mV, and the decomposition potential difference was 146.0 mV, which indicates the advantages of W2N/Mo2N over the others. The nucleation and decomposition potential difference of Mo2N was 39.6 and 161.1 mV, respectively, whereas that of W2N was 33.5 and 164.0 mV, respectively. The nucleation and decomposition potential difference of MOF-C was 50.1 and 156.7 mV, respectively. The comparison shows that W2N/Mo2N had the strongest effect on promoting the nucleation and decomposition of Li2S, followed by W2N, Mo2N, and finally MOF-C. The Li2S nucleation experiment is another effective way to determine the effect of the sulfur hosts in promoting Li2S nucleation. When the electrolyte contains Li2S8, the discharge under the set conditions can simulate the Li2S nucleation process in Li-S batteries. By recording the time-current curve and the amount of active material, the specific capacity of each stage in the Li2S nucleation process can be calculated to measure the catalytic activity of the sulfur hosts. In Fig. 3(i), the specific capacities of Li2S nucleation of W2N/Mo2N, Mo2N, W2N, and MOF-C are 51.9195, 46.8245, 35.2907, and 27.9715 mA h g−1, respectively. In the Li2S nucleation experiment, nucleation specific capacity is affected by multiple factors such as adsorption, catalytic ability, and specific surface area. Thus, the catalytic effects of Mo2N and MOF-C are stronger than that of W2N. The time at which the current reaches its maximum can reflect the catalytic nucleation energy barrier to some extent. The comparison shows that W2N/Mo2N has the best catalytic nucleation effect and the highest nucleation specific capacity in the Li2S nucleation experiment. To investigate the LiPSs state during the charging and discharging process, in situ Raman tests were performed on W2N/Mo2N and MOF-C, and the test source was irradiated on the cathode through the electrolyte [38–40]. Fig. 4 (a) illustrates the waterfall spectrum, and Fig. 4(c) presents the contour profile of the Raman results of MOF-C. The sampling voltage point is distributed in different phase transition regions during the charging and discharging process. As shown in Fig. 4(b), the peaks representing S8 2−, S4 2−, S6 2−/S4 2−, and S4 2−/S3 2− appear at 152, 219, 450, and 470 cm−1, respectively. With the discharge-charge process from point A to point L, the peak intensity of soluble LiPSs tends to decrease first and then increase, reaching the weakest at point F. However, the peaks representing soluble LiPSs did not disappear during the whole process. The in-situ Raman results of W2N/Mo2N are presented in Fig. 4(d–f). When the discharge process reaches point E, the peak representing soluble LiPSs completely disappears and reappears when the charging process reaches point I. These results indicate that the liquid-solid conversion efficiency of W2N/Mo2N during the discharge process was much higher than that of MOF-C, and the conversion rate of soluble LiPSs to insoluble LiPSs was significantly enhanced. Similarly, the soluble LiPSs were rapidly converted after the decomposition of Li2S in the initial stage of the charging process, and the relevant peaks could not be detected. However, as the charging process continues, the soluble LiPSs continuously accumulate to a certain concentration before being detected. The in situ Raman results indicate that W2N/Mo2N effectively realizes the adsorption and catalytic conversion of soluble LiPSs. The theoretical simulations and experiments on the adsorption and catalytic abilities of W2N/Mo2N confirmed its potential to be used as a sulfur host in Li-S batteries. The electrochemical performance of the sulfur hosts is shown in Fig. 5 [17]. To investigate the redox process of the battery, CV test was performed (Fig. 5a) at 0.1 mV s−1. The two reduction peaks represent the reduction process of S8 to soluble LiPSs and soluble LiPSs to Li2S, respectively. The reduction peak potential of W2N/Mo2N was found to be higher than that of the other sulfur hosts, which indicates that the phase transition energy barrier to be overcome is lower. The peak potentials representing the oxidation of Li2S to soluble LiPSs and soluble LiPSs to S8 are E pa1 and E pa2, respectively, as shown in the illustration. W2N/Mo2N has lower E pa1 and E pa2, and the potential difference between E pa1 and E pa2 for W2N/Mo2N is the smallest. This means that W2N/Mo2N has the lowest Li2S oxidation energy barrier, and the conversion process of soluble LiPSs to S8 is faster. In addition, the oxidation reaction of Li-S batteries includes two steps, but due to the same reaction rate of generating and consuming LiPS from ordinary sulfur cathode electrodes, similar charge transfer and ion diffusion rates, the reaction can proceed quickly. Therefore, the oxidation peak presents a single peak. But W2N/Mo2N, W2N, and Mo2N as sulfur host materials exhibited varying degrees of peak splitting, indicating their effective catalytic activity for electrochemical reactions. The voltage at 10 μA cm−2 above the baseline current was defined as the onset potential. The onset potentials of the oxidation and reduction peaks of the sulfur hosts are shown in Fig. 5(b). W2N/Mo2N has the lowest onset potential during oxidation and the highest onset potential during reduction, indicating that W2N/Mo2N has good electrocatalytic ability for fast redox transformation. Fig. 5(c) shows the charge-discharge curves at a current density of 0.2 C, where ΔV is the polarization voltage between the battery charge and discharge curves (ΔV was measured at a discharge depth of 50%). The value of ΔV is affected by many factors, including the ohmic polarization caused by the internal resistance of the battery and the redox potential of the battery. The smaller the ΔV, the faster the electrochemical kinetics is and the smaller the polarization of the battery is, so the performance of the battery will be greatly improved. The ΔV values of W2N/Mo2N, Mo2N, W2N, and MOF-C are 0.19, 0.22, 0.26, and 0.27 V, respectively. W2N/Mo2N reduced the ohmic polarization and the phase transformation energy barrier, which is consistent with the CV results. Fig. 5(d) presents the Nyquist (electrochemical impedance spectroscopy, EIS) results of the sulfur hosts in the initial state, showing that the surface and charge transfer impedance of MOF-C is about 100 Ω. The diffusion impedance values of W2N/Mo2N and W2N are roughly equivalent, whereas the diffusion resistance of Mo2N is relatively higher than the other hosts. The surface and charge transfer resistance slightly increased after Mo2N doping, reaching about 110 Ω. However, after W2N doping, the resistance decreased. W2N has the lowest resistance, followed by W2N/Mo2N, which is consistent with the conductivity analysis. The ion conductivity testing of materials has been added, and the test results are shown in Fig. S17. Among them, the ion conductivity of W2N was the highest. The conductivity of Mo2N/W2N was between W2N and Mo2N, which meant the addition of W2N improved the ion conductivity of Mo2N. Before cycling, the batteries were activated by cycling at a rate of 0.1 C for 5 cycles. Fig. 5(e) presents the short-term cycle performance at a current density of 0.5 C. W2N/Mo2N delivered an initial charge specific capacity of 971.4 mA h g−1 and remained at 922.4 mA h g−1 with a capacity retention rate of up to 94.96%. Compared with Mo2N (1st: 826.4 mA h g−1; 260th: 706.4 mA h g−1), W2N (1st: 773.7 mA h g−1; 260th: 589.2 mA h g−1), and MOF-C (1st: 597.7 mA h g−1; 260th: 507.9 mA h g−1), W2N/Mo2N has higher capacity and cycle stability. The rate performance is shown in Fig. 5(f). The current density ranges from 0.1 to 2 C, and the charge specific capacities of W2N/Mo2N are 1631.4, 1211.4, 951.3, 723.9, and 569.5 mA h g−1, respectively. When the current density returns to 0.1 C, the specific capacity recovers to 1180.4 mA h g−1. The capacities of Mo2N are 1227.3, 905.8, 796.6, 670.7, and 202.7 mA h g−1, respectively, and the value recovers to 925.5 mA h g−1 when the current density returns to 0.1 C. The capacities of W2N are 1103.6, 802, 711.3, 633.1, and 459.4 mA h g−1, respectively, and the value recovers to 830.5 mA h g−1 when the current density returns to 0.1 C. The capacities of MOF-C are 761.5, 564.5, 538.6, 459.1, and 358.3 mA h g−1, respectively, and the specific capacity recovers to 830.5 mA h g−1 when the current density returns to 0.1 C. The rate performance shows that the strong adsorption of Mo2N and the strong catalytic ability of W2N are in a balanced state. Adsorption is dominant at low current density, and catalytic ability is dominant at high current density. The W2N/Mo2N heterostructure combines the advantages of the two and accelerates the migration of ions and electrons, allowing Li-S batteries to achieve optimal performance. Fig. 5(g) shows the cycle performance at 1 C. The initial charge specific capacity of W2N/Mo2N is 880.5 mA h g−1 and remains at 589.3 mA h g−1 after 980 cycles with a decay rate of 0.034% per cycle. The initial charge specific capacity of Mo2N and W2N is similar, both around 600 mA h g−1, slightly higher than that of MOF-C (537.2 mA h g−1), but far lower than W2N/Mo2N. After 980 cycles, the remaining capacity of Mo2N, W2N, and MOF-C is also at a disadvantage compared to W2N/Mo2N. It can be seen that the change of the capacity of the four cathodes at 1 C is quite different from that at a low current density. W2N/Mo2N combines the advantages of W2N and Mo2N and accelerates the transmission of electrons and ions, allowing the highest capacity and cycle stability. Fig. 5(h) shows a three-dimensional comparison of the performance of this work with some highly cited heterostructures as sulfur hosts under four different current densities (0.5, 1, 2, and 3 C). W2N/Mo2N has the advantage of high capacity in short cycle as well as excellent stability in long-term performance. To investigate the cycle performance under high current density, the batteries were tested at 3 C, as shown in Fig. 5(i). The initial and final charge specific capacities of W2N/Mo2N are 442.4 and 269 mA h g−1, respectively, with capacity decay of 0.0196% per cycle. As shown in Fig. S18, MOF-C (1st: 146.7, 2000th: 71.3 mA h g−1, decay rate: 0.0257%) only enhanced the conductivity of the cathode and realized a small amount of LiPSs adsorption, leading to the worst cycle performance. W2N (1st: 164.6, 2000th: 116.3 mA h g−1, decay rate: 0.0147%) improved the conductivity of the electrode and reduced the energy barrier of redox conversion and migration. Moreover, W2N has a certain LiPSs adsorption ability, which makes its cycle performance slightly better than that of MOF-C. Owing to the strong adsorption ability of Mo2N to LiPSs, the capacity of Mo2N (1st: 242.2, 2000th: 93.5 mA h g−1, decay rate: 0.0307%) experienced increase and decrease before 900 cycles, and the initial value is higher than that of W2N. However, with the deactivation of adsorption sites and slightly lower conductivity, the capacity fading of Mo2N after 900 cycles is particularly obvious; moreover, the capacity is lower than that of W2N. W2N/Mo2N is endowed with the strong adsorption ability of Mo2N and the strong catalytic ability of W2N, as well as efficient ion and electron migration. Thus, it maintained high capacity and stability over 2000 cycles, achieving the “1 + 1 > 2” effect. It is necessary to test the charging and discharging cycle of high sulfur load, as shown in Fig. S19, a cycle curve of W2N/Mo2N with a sulfur load of 4.5 mg cm−2 at 0.5 C. The battery showed an initial capacity of 787.9 mA h g−1 and was able to maintain 563.7 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles. W2N/Mo2N as S host materials displayed excellent performance. 3 Conclusions In summary, hollow MOF-C realized sulfur storage and preliminary confinement of sulfur, followed by the construction of numerous uniformly distributed W2N/Mo2N heterostructures as a functional modification. The W2N/Mo2N heterostructure offers strong adsorption and high catalytic abilities, and the heterostructure interface realizes acceleration of electron and ion transport owing to its high intrinsic conductivity and built-in electric field. The adsorption of LiPSs is achieved through Lewis covalent bonds, lithium bonds, and Van der Waals forces. Furthermore, the heterogeneous interface provides high conductivity and acceleration for the transmission of electrons and ions, and they combine the catalytic ability to increase the efficiency of LiPSs conversion and decrease the energy barrier of LiPSs oxidation and reduction. Consequently, the dynamics of battery reactions is enhanced. Moreover, the LiPSs conversion efficiency was improved and the energy barriers of LiPSs oxidation and reduction were reduced through the high conductivity and accelerated electron and ion transmission offered by the heterogeneous interface combined with the catalytic ability, ultimately enhancing the dynamics of battery reactions. Thus, the W2N/Mo2N cathode delivered stable long-term cycling (over 2000 cycles) at 3 C with an average attenuation of only 0.0196% per cycle. This study presents a design approach for a sulfur host to facilitate the commercialization of Li-S batteries. Experimental section Experimental details can be found in the Supporting Information. coredata.dc:description: The practical application of lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries, as promising next-generation batteries, is hindered by their shuttle effect and the slow redox kinetics. Herein, a tungsten and molybdenum nitride heterostructure functionalized with hollow metal-organic framework-derived carbon (W2N/Mo2N) was proposed as the sulfur host. The hollow spherical structure provides storage space for sulfur, enhances electrical conductivity, and inhibits volume expansion. The metal atoms in the nitrides bonded with lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) through Lewis covalent bonds, enhancing the high catalytic activity of the nitrides and effectively reducing the energy barrier of LiPSs redox conversion. Moreover, the high intrinsic conductivity of nitrides and the ability of the heterostructure interface to accelerate electron/ion transport improved the Li+ transmission. By leveraging the combined properties of strong adsorption and high catalytic activity, the sulfur host effectively inhibited the shuttle effect and accelerated the redox kinetics of LiPSs. High-efficiency Li+ transmission, strong adsorption, and the efficient catalytic conversion activities of LiPSs in the heterostructure were experimentally and theoretically verified. The results indicate that the W2N/Mo2N cathode provides stable, and long-term cycling (over 2000 cycles) at 3 C with a low attenuation rate of 0.0196% per cycle. The design strategy of a twinborn nitride heterostructure thus provides a functionalized solution for advanced Li-S batteries.
